Afrobeatis a combination of traditionalGhanamusic,jazz,highlife,funk, andchantedvocals,fused withPercussion instrumentpercussionandvocalstyles, popularised inAfricain the 1970s. It was named byNigerianmulti-MusicianinstrumentalistandbandleaderFela Kuti, who is responsible for the creation of the style and spreading the genre outside ofGhana.cite journalGrassRandall F.Fela Anikulapo-Kuti: The Art of an Afrobeat RebelThe Drama Review: TDRMIT Press30131â€“148114571710.2307/1145717Fela used it to revolutionize musical structure as well as the political context in his native Nigeria. It was Kuti who coined the term "afrobeat" upon his return from a U.S. tour with his group Nigeria '70 (formerly Koola Lobitos). Afrobeat featureschants,call-and-responsevocals, and complex, interacting rhythms.

The new sound hailed from a club that he established called theNew Afrika ShrineAfrika Shrine. Upon arriving in Nigeria, Kuti also changed the name of his group to Africa '70. The band maintained a five-year residency in the Afrika Shrine from 1970 to 1975 while afrobeat thrived among Nigerian youth. Afrobeat is now one of the most recognizable music genres in the world and has influenced as many Western musicians as it has African ones with its exuberant style andpolyrhythms.
article.heading: Origins
article.paragraph: Afrobeat originated from Ghanahighlifeand heavy African drumbeats.cite webhttp://www.allmusic.com/album/ghana-soundz-afrobeat-funk-and-fusion-in-the-70s-mw0000259942Ghana Soundz: Afrobeat, Funk and Fusion in the 70's - Various Artists - Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards - AllMusicChris NicksonAllMusiccite webhttp://worldmusiccentral.org/2013/08/29/the-infectious-songs-of-ghanaian-afrobeat/The Infectious Songs of Ghanaian Afrobeatworldmusiccentral.orgIt was later exported to the southern part ofNigeriain the 1970s, Fela Kuti, experimented with many different forms of contemporary music of the time.cite web18 July 2012Clyde Macfarlanehttp://thinkafricapress.com/ghana/album-review-konkoma-afrobeat-highlifeAlbum Review: KonKomaThink Africa Press2012-07-182015-03-22cite webhttp://www.rhapsody.com/blog/post/radio-afrobeat-airwavesRadio: AfroBeat AirwavesRhapsodyPrevalent in his andLagbaja's music are native African harmonies and rhythms, taking different elements and combining, modernizing, and improvising upon them.Politicsare essential to Afrobeat, since founder Kuti used social criticism to pave the way for social change. His message can be described as confrontational and controversial, which can be related to the political climate of most of the African countries in the 1970s, many of which were dealing with political injustice and military corruption while recovering from the transition from colonial governments to self-determination. As the genre spread throughout the African continent many bands took up the style. The recordings of these bands and their songs were rarely heard or exported outside the originating countries but many can now be found oncompilation albumsandCDsfrom specialist record shops.

article.heading: Influence
article.paragraph: Manyjazzmusicians have been attracted to afrobeat. FromRoy Ayersin the 1970s toRandy Westonin the 1990s, there have been collaborations that have resulted in albums such asAfrica: Centre of the Worldby Roy Ayers, released on thePolydor RecordsPolydorelabel in 1981. In 1994Branford Marsalis, the American jazz saxophonist, included samples of Fela's "Beast of No Nation" on hisBuckshot LeFonque (album)Buckshot LeFonquealbum. The new generation ofDisc JockeyDJsand musicians of the 2000s who have fallen in love with both Kuti's material and other rare releases have made compilations andremixesof these recordings, thus re-introducing the genre to new generations of listeners and fans ofAfro pop musicafropopandGroove (music)groove(see#afrobeatsAfrobeatssection below).

Afrobeat has profoundly influenced important contemporary producers and musicians likeBrian EnoandDavid Byrne, who credit Fela Kuti as an essential influence. Both worked onTalking Heads' highly acclaimed 1980 albumRemain In Light, which brought polyrhythmic afrobeat influences to Western music. More recently, the horn section ofAntibalashave been guest musicians onTV On The Radio's highly acclaimed 2008 albumDear Science, as well as on British bandFoals (band)Foals' 2008 album,Antidotes. Some Afrobeat influence can also be found in the music ofVampire WeekendandPaul Simon.

article.paragraph: There are several active afrobeat bands worldwide today.
